title: 114_s1337
content: The "Strengthening Privacy, Oversight, and Transparency Act" or the "SPOT Act" includes provisions to expand the oversight authority of the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board to cover foreign intelligence activities. It also requires the submission of whistleblower complaints to the Board. Section 1061 of the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 is amended to allow employees of the intelligence community to submit whistleblower complaints related to privacy or civil liberties concerns to the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board for investigation. The amended Section 1061 allows intelligence community employees to submit whistleblower complaints to the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board. Employees have the authority to submit complaints in addition to any other existing laws. The Board can take action on complaints regardless of actions taken under other laws. The amended Section 1061 allows intelligence community employees to submit whistleblower complaints to the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board without hindrance. Individuals can submit complaints and the recipient can take independent action on them. Definitions for 'congressional intelligence committees' and 'intelligence community' are provided. SEC. 4 amends Section 1061(g) of the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004, removing the requirement to submit a written request to the Attorney General. Paragraph (2) is eliminated, and paragraphs (3) and (4) are redesignated as (2) and (3) respectively. SEC. 5 addresses the appointment of staff for the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board. SEC. 5 amends the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 regarding the appointment of staff for the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board. It allows the Board to exercise the chairman's authority in the absence of a chairman. SEC. 5 amends the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 to adjust the appointment of staff for the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board, allowing the Board to exercise the chairman's authority in the chairman's absence. Amendments include changes to subsections (h) and (i) regarding the Executive Schedule levels. The amendments made by subsection (a) adjust the Executive Schedule levels for the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board appointments, effective upon enactment of the Act. The amendments made by paragraphs (2)(A) and (3) of subsection (a) regarding compensation changes will take effect on the first day of the first pay period after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, current members of the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board have the option to serve full time. Current members of the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board have the option to serve full-time or part-time in accordance with the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004. Current members of the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board can choose to serve full-time or part-time, with specific limitations and conditions in place. Current members of the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board can choose to serve full-time or part-time, with specific limitations and conditions in place, after the date on which the current member makes the election. The Attorney General must inform the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board about government activities under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978, including providing detailed reports and court decisions.
